Award.AwardTitle: Operation of the CLIVAR and Carbon Hydrographic Data Office at UCSD/SIO, 2014-2018
Award.AbstractNarration:
Overview: The CLIVAR and Carbon Hydrographic Data Office (CCHDO) is the repository, assembly center, and distribution center for full-depth global ocean hydrographic, carbon, and tracer data. These data are a product of several international research programs (the World Ocean circulation experiment (WOCE), the CLImate VARiability and predictability program (CLIVAR), the International Ocean Carbon Coordination Project (IOCCP), the Global Ocean Ship-based Hydrographic Investigations Program (GO-SHIP)), and national research programs - past, present and to come. Whenever possible the CCHDO provides these data in three community formats: WHP-Exchange, netCDF, and WOCE. The CCHDO seeks to assure that these data and their associated documentation are prepared and made readily available for immediate research and education uses, and that these data have a long service life. The CCHDO?s primary window to the research community is via its web site . The CCHDO maintains ties with designated national data archives like NODC/WDC-A to see that the entirety of its public holdings is formally archived and up to date at the archive.

Intellectual Merit: The CCHDO brings together, verifies, and corrects content and format errors in the hydrographic, and tracer data used in large scale ocean carbon, global change, water mass, and circulation studies. The team assembles the data with relevant documentation, and carefully prepares them for dissemination and archive. In addition they work to promote appropriate methodology, community standards, communications, and data compatibility. The CCHDO data are created by over 100 data originators worldwide, sometimes with 5 or more investigators separately contributing to one bottle data file. The CCHDO makes it possible for all data users to cope with the temporal-, content-, and format-related file diversity these different originators engender. The CCHDO brings data together to a common content and readability standard, thereby greatly reducing the difficulties research and education data users encounter. A strong additional advantage is that the documentation associated with the data are collected, reorganized to a common standard (where possible), and preserved with the data.

Broader Impacts: The CCHDO enhances research infrastructure, the broad dissemination of results, and the integration of research and education. While the CCHDO does not generate new data, it makes the data better and more usable, thus more far reaching and ultimately more scientifically and socially relevant. Via the CCHDO?s actions, present-day and future US and international users of these CTD, routine hydrography, ocean carbon, and tracer ocean profile data can easily use any of the data files written in the ASCII or netCDF exchange formats. This both reduces the personnel costs to data users to import and use data and also makes these data available to a much wider audience in the research, educational, and broader communities who do not employ data specialists. Moreover, the careful assembly of documentation with the data helps to assure a service lifetime for the data far into the future, contributing to a broad range of future studies of long-term ocean variability. The clean-up of the data and rewriting into accepted data formats also make the data much more straightforward to import into computer models. The CCHDO supports CLIVAR and carbon science programs, and is a data component of a global observing system for the physical climate and carbon dioxide system. The CCHDO is hence part of a larger international effort to monitor the ocean?s response to climate change. The CCHDO puts into play the fundamental concept that data collected belong to the community, and should be available to the community at large.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CLIVAR and Carbon Hydrographic Data Office (CCHDO) at the UCSD Scripps Institution of Oceanography has the fundamental mission of being the repository, assembly center, and distribution center for global ocean CTD, hydrographic, carbon, and tracer data of the highest quality and utility. These data are a product of WOCE, CLIVAR, the International Ocean Carbon Coordination Project, GO-SHIP, and other oceanographic research programs - past, present and to come. Whenever possible the CCHDO provides these data in three widely-used community formats: WHP-Exchange, netCDF, and WOCE. The CCHDO seeks to ensure that these data and their associated documentation are prepared and made readily available for immediate research and education uses, and that these data have a long service life. File-to-file near-lockstep consistency - "if you can read one CCHDO data file you can read them all" - is a key goal. The CCHDO's primary window to the research community is via its web site http://cchdo.ucsd.edu. The CCHDO maintains ties with NOAA/NCEI to see that the entirety of its public holdings is formally archived and up to date at the archive.

 

The CCHDO is an intermediary between investigators carrying out CTD/hydrographic field work and the research/education community, saving data users a great deal of effort by bringing disparate files, information, and formats to a common standard. (Otherwise each data user would need to do this.) At the CCHDO, the CTD, hydrographic, ocean carbon, and tracer data used in ocean circulation and climate studies are brought together, verified, assembled with relevant documentation, and carefully prepared for discovery, dissemination and archive. With data files from over 1900 cruises and more than 100,000 profiles, it is challenging to maintain universal file readability. The CCHDO works with data originators to deal with imprecision and minor oversights in formats and parameter specifics, and with the hydrographic data community to promote appropriate methodologies, applicable community standards, communications, and data compatibility.

 

During the grant period the performance and supportability of the machinery underlying the CCHDO web site were greatly improved. Development focused on absolutely necessary features: enabling searches for data and sending data files to users. The grant supported separating the programmatic logic of the website (the "face" of the CCHDO) from the underlying data management itself. Wherever possible, the CCHDO relies on outside standards, with speed and data integrity always considered. The now-minimalist appearance of the CCHDO web site belies increased speed, accuracy, reliability, and search power, and some significant new features. There has been continued adjustment of web site features to meet user needs. The CCHDO continues to improve data management practices, and deal with any type of data and documentation needed for the programs it supports. 

 

During the grant, the CCHDO established weekly (moving to bi-weekly) telecon data meetings between a host of US data managers. There is typically a pre-announced focus each session. These meetings engender active discussion, technical/strategic coordination, and many improvements in and between the groups, benefitting a wide range of data users and data originators. Their elevation to the Marine Data Cluster under the Earth Science Information Partners is an indication of their importance to the broader community

 

There has been a massive increase in the CCHDO's data and cruise documentation holdings. The downside is that the present CCHDO funding is insufficient to fully keep up the management all data. All received data are posted as is. For creating integrated data products, a triage process is used, essentially placing US GO-SHIP data first, international GO-SHIP (and related) data second, and all other data third in terms of priority to address format, data and documentation issues. The CCHDO continued to make progress in reconstituting essential cruise/data documentation from past cruises, adding thousands of new pages of cruise documentation.

 

Undergraduate student training and experience remains integral to the CCHDO. Students work with an experienced team to handle data and documentation, and web site development.

 

The CCHDO Director, Dr. James Swift, retired at the end of June 2018, and Dr. Karen Stocks, SIO, was appointed as the new CCHDO Director. Swift remains active as an advisor, and the transition has been smooth.
